description: Attested since the 1690s, from Latin curvus (“bent, curved”), ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *(s)ker- (“to bend, curve, turn”) + *-wós. Doublet of curb, shrink, carcer, and cancer.

entries.meaning: A gentle bend, such as in a road.
examples: You should slow down when approaching a curve.

entries.meaning: A simple figure containing no straight portions and no angles; a curved line.
examples: She scribbled a curve on the paper.

entries.meaning: A grading system based on the scale of performance of a group used to normalize a right-skewed grade distribution (with more lower scores) into a bell curve, so that more can receive higher grades, regardless of their actual knowledge of the subject.
examples: The teacher was nice and graded the test on a curve.

entries.meaning: (analytic geometry) A continuous map from a one-dimensional space to a multidimensional space.
(geometry) A one-dimensional figure of non-zero length; the graph of a continuous map from a one-dimensional space.
(algebraic geometry) An algebraic curve; a polynomial relation of the planar coordinates.
(informal, usually in the plural) The attractive shape of a woman's body.

verbs.description: curve (third-person singular simple present curves, present participle curving, simple past and past participle curved)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cause to swerve from a straight course.
examples: to curve a ball in pitching it

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To bend or turn gradually from a given direction.
examples: the road curves to the right

entries.meaning: (transitive) To grade on a curve (bell curve of a normal distribution).
examples: The teacher will curve the test.

entries.meaning: (transitive) (slang) To reject, to turn down romantic advances.
examples: I was once curved three times by the same woman.
